newsitem.title: USA: Palm Beach County, Fla., asked to issue arena debt.
newsitem.headline: Palm Beach County, Fla., asked to issue arena debt.

text.p: A private development group has asked Florida's Palm Beach County to issue taxable bonds to finance conversion of the Palm Beach Jai Alai Fronton into a 10,000-seat arena.

County debt manager John Long said Wednesday that the county commission agreed to begin negotiations with The Arena Group, a private development group headed by owners of the Florida Bobcats arena football team and the Palm Beach Lions hockey team. But the county has not agreed to issue the bonds.

"That's part of the negotiation," Long said. "The proposal asks for us to pledge non-ad valorem revenues in support of taxable bonds. It said they (The Arena Group) would guarantee the debt service. But we've got to be comfortable with an appropriate guarantee of the debt service."
Alternatively, he said, the debt could take the form of a private placement, or possibly a corporate debt issue.

The Arena Group's proposal stipulates that the group would contribute $2.7 million a year toward estimated debt service of $3.5 million a year. The rest would be paid via a surcharge on tickets to arena events.
Palm Beach County would own the arena but would not be responsible for any operating losses.

The county hopes to sign a contract within 45 days so renovation of the 4,000-seat fronton could begin in December and finish by September 1998. The county hopes to open the arena before the demolition of the West Palm Beach Auditorium, where the two teams now play.
The county is negotiating to sell the auditoriumn to a private construction company, Catalfumo Construction, which plans to raze it by March 1999.
